column4: I just deleted a very important file that took me hours to make. It was on my Desktop. Every time I open the Trash it freezes (just the Trash window). I NEED that file. Can anyone help? What is going on? Can I manually get it back form the terminal?
Go to ~/.Trash in terminal
I'm not familiar with all the terminal commands. Could you elaborate on your statement? Thanks.
Basically, do "mv ~/.Trash/<yourfile> ~", and you'll have it in your home directory again.
many thanks. I will try this now.
If you don't know the name exactly, you can type some letters and use tab-completion.
I get an error that the file is not there. I know the file name and I tried again many times but no success. I really don't want to redo all my work.
Are you sure the name is correct? Be aware that Linux is case sensitive in files...
very sure.
Was the file on a special file system? There are several Trash folders...
If you have some time, you could do "sudo find / -iname <yourfile>" as well... that will find it.
No, just my Desktop. It was a PNG image. And I will try that, too.
the search is still running, but already it confirmed it was in ~/.Trash/
In that case, the first command should have worked... check that you made no mistakes when using that one-.
The way its shown in the "find" output is how you need to use it in "mv".
my Hard Drive is huge, how can I stop the search? Close the window?
Close the window or Ctrl+C :)
so I do "mv /home/steven/.Trash/header.png" and it will move to my home directory? Do I need "sudo"?
You need to add a target at the end... like "/home/steven"
No need to sudo.
I still get this: mv: missing destination file operand after `/home/steven/.Trash/header.png'
I still get this: mv: missing destination file operand after `/home/steven/.Trash/header.png'
